Graphical abstract The structure-property relationship of the MOF-based electrocatalysts is elaborated for different energy-/sensing redox reactions. Studies have extensively addressed the development of electrocatalytic technologies for energy storage and conversion, fuel production, and environmental protection. Electrode processes such as different oxidation and reduction reactions play a vital and significant role in these technologies. In this regard, efficient, inexpensive, and stable electrocatalysts capable can significantly promote electrochemical reactions. Unique features of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) such as their high porosity, tunable structure, size, and pore shape, high surface area, and redox properties have introduced them as an ideal electrocatalyst candidate. This review is thus aimed at elucidating the role of MOF-based materials (pristine, derivatives and composites) as efficient electrocatalysts in energy and sensing-related oxidation and reduction reactions such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), urea oxidation reaction (UOR), alcohol oxidation reaction (AOR), nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), and glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) in advanced energy and sensing devices. Also, the structure–property relationship of the electrocatalyst was elaborated for each electrocatalytic reaction. Finally, perspectives on the potential research topics for practical use of MOF-based electrocatalysts are addressed. The present review can improve the interest in MOF-based electrocatalysts to study different oxidation and reduction reactions in energy and sensing systems. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Electrocatalyst Oxidation reaction Reduction reaction 1 Introduction The sustainability of human society depends on the development of advanced techniques for clean energy generation [1–4]. These techniques can also resolve environmental problems. The ever-increasing consumption of fossil fuels has led to serious energy and environmental problems which can be resolved by the development of various technologies such as fuel cells, conversion of carbon dioxide to fuel, water electrolysis, and metal-air batteries [5–7]. The urgent demand for efficient environmental protection measures has motivated the development of green alternatives for the conventional synthesis methods in which electrochemistry plays a decisive role. Electrochemistry is an interesting and attractive field of applied studies as diverse oxidation and reduction reactions are performed with the aid of electrochemical agents. An electrochemical reaction occurs at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte, through oxidation or reduction reactions by electron transitions [8]. Under proper and precise potential control, the electrode will act as a free energy source. The electrons passing through the solution will be determined by measuring the current with high sensitivity. Electrochemistry can offer efficient and easy reactions for resolving serious issues of depleting natural resources of fossil fuels and environmental pollution. Numerous chemicals with various applications are currently produced by electrochemical methods [9]. An electrocatalyst is defined as a substance on the surface of the electrode which creates new pathways to accelerate the electrochemical reaction without changing the potential. Electrochemical reactions refer to a group of chemical reactions involving electron transitions between atoms, molecules, and ions that means reduction and oxidation reactions [10,11]. Electrochemical reactions are complex processes related to the surface reaction and electrocatalyst behavior. Oxidation reaction occurs at the anode while the reduction reaction occurs at the cathode. In a spontaneous chemical reaction, electron transitions are equalized and directed by an electric current, converting chemical energy into electrical energy. In a nonspontaneous chemical reaction, electrical energy is converted into chemical energy by an external current. Electrochemical devices such as supercapacitors, fuel cells, batteries, and electrolytic cells have received a lot of attention [12,13]. Various oxidation and reduction reactions such as hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), alcohol oxidation reaction (AOR), urea oxidation reaction (UOR), and glycerol oxidation reaction (GOR) occur in these devices (Fig. 1 ). Some of these half-reactions are very slow, requiring large overpotentials which can be overcome by using an efficient catalyst. Regarding the difficulty of controlling and calibration of influential factors in electrochemistry such as pH value, working conditions of electrodes and the instrument, and ohmic drop, the study of the behavior of classic materials such as IrO2 and Pt/C and comparing their performance with the studied catalysts can be very helpful. The amount of the applied electrocatalyst can also be important, such that less sample can be more effective for better evaluation of its performance and better use of all active sites. On the other hand, more catalysts can also be useful in determining its overall performance. Regarding the urgent need to develop technologies for energy storage and conversion, pristine metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), MOF derivatives and MOF-based composites have recently gained considerable attention to accelerate important reduction and oxidation reactions (Fig. 2 ). MOFs are a group of crystalline materials encompassing metal ions or clusters as nodes and organic ligands as linkers [14–18]. This group of materials can be synthesized by various methods such as solvo/hydro-thermal, microwave, and ball milling at lower costs. The wide variety of metal salts, as well as organic ligands, has led to the synthesis of MOFs with different sizes, geometries, and structures. Due to their unique properties such as low density, large specific surface area, and abundant pores, these compounds can be used in various fields such as sensors, luminescence, drug delivery, gas storage, energy storage and conversion, and catalysis [19–21]. Pristine MOFs are as pre-catalysts that merely produce active phases during the electrocatalytic treatment. During electrocatalysis treatment the chemical bonds break and form the metal sites. In some reactions maybe form the intermediates that can react with organic linkers. So the determining of electrochemical stability is vital. A MOF pre-catalyst does not display a significant change in total shape and if just its surface converts to active phases its bulk structure remains and it acts as a pre-catalyst [22]. The utilization of MOFs in the field of electrochemical energy conversion has gained increasing popularity [23,24]. For example, high surface area is benefit to transfer of electron and ions between the electrode surface and electrolyte and boost the electrocatalytic performance. Abundant pores in MOF structures prepare a lot of sites to do electrocatalytic reaction on the surface and improve the performance. MOF-based materials have a tunable nature in unsaturated coordination sites, pore size, pore surroundings and functionalized ligands. Therefore it is easy to tune and promote their electrocatalytic performance. In addition, structural defects and crystal orientation in MOF-based materials are effective items to promote their electrocatalytic performance. These specific characters of MOF-based materials make them different from other electrocatalysts. Despite their versatile capabilities related to electrocatalysts, some disadvantages of MOFs including their poor stability and low conductivity, have limited their widespread application. Therefore, the rational design of MOFs for their electrochemical applications will be very effective and decisive in the future of these compounds. Actually, structure–property relationship tune the property of materials through the structure and it is effective to discover next-generation electrocatalysts with favorable and novel properties. On the other hand, many reports have suggested the proper performance of MOF composites and MOF derivatives in different electrochemical applications [25]. The future of these materials as electrocatalysts with good performance depends on resolving these disadvantages. One of the key and important factors for an electrocatalyst is high electrical conductivity. MOFs, however, possess poor conductivity which must be resolved before their wide application as electrocatalysts [26]. Strategies such as mixed-valence, redox matching, and donor–acceptor interactions can resolve the mentioned issue. Improving inherent conductivity of catalysts is one aspect of the issue while the other one is electron transfer, which can be obtained by contact between the electrocatalyst particles and the electron collecting substrates such as copper/nickel/silver foam, indium tin oxide (ITO) glass, and glassy carbon (GC). In most studies, electrocatalysts are placed on these substrates; electrocatalyst is connected to the substrate through binders such as Nafion or polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE). Meanwhile, the best method is the direct growth of electrocatalyst particles on the substrate through the electrochemical technique. In this regard, steps must be taken to find more effective and simpler techniques for achieving more stable, high-performance electrocatalysts. The growth of MOFs thin films or nanocrystals on conductive substrates is relatively difficult; therefore, efforts should be made to make high-performance MOFs through reactive seeding, direct synthesis, and secondary synthesis. Based on the above explanations, and due to the importance of MOFs, MOF derivatives and MOF composites as electrocatalysts, this review presents a comprehensive overview of the performance of these materials as electrocatalysts with emphasis on their advantages and disadvantages. For each reaction, several electrocatalysts will be mentioned and their design, performance, and improvement solutions will be discussed. The challenges involved in the way of using these materials as electrocatalysts will be also addressed. 2 Importance of oxidation and reduction reactions High consumption rates of fossil fuels and environmental pollution have led researchers to develop energy storage and conversion techniques [27,28]. Metal-air batteries (MABs) and proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) are the next generations of clean energy [29,30]. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) occurs at the cathode in MABs and PEMFCs. The O=O bond is very strong and its breakdown requires high levels of energy. Efficient electrocatalysts are required to overcome this energy barrier. In PEMFCs, the cathodic half-reaction of ORR is done by different intermediates such as OOH*, O*, and OH* and through different adsorption/desorption pathways. This half-reaction has a much slower pace compared to the anodic half-reaction (i.e. hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR)). Therefore, the catalytic acceleration of the cathodic half-reaction is highly essential. Expensive Pt-based electrocatalysts have been employed to accelerate ORR. The poor stability of these electrocatalysts is another limitation, hindering their widespread application. In this regard, extensive studies have been devoted to developing efficient, cost-effective, and stable ORR electrocatalysts for replacement with Pt-based materials electrocatalysts. The consumption of fossil fuels in the transportation sector has raised the emissions of pollutants and greenhouse gases, especially CO2. As fossil fuels are unsustainable in the long run, diverse sustainable and clean alternative fuels are under development. Meanwhile, special attention has been paid to polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) such as ethanol, methanol, and hydrogen with versatile benefits such as low toxicity, high volumetric density of energy, and easier storage. Alcohols such as ethanol, methanol, and glycerol possess higher energy density compared to hydrogen; they are also more flexible, less expensive and toxic, with easier storage and transportation [31]. Current studies are focused on the use of clean energy sources such as direct alcohol fuel cells (DAFCs) with promising advantages such as low toxicity, high volumetric energy density, and easier storage [32,33]. In PEMFCs, HOR generates proton in anode side. These fuel cells applied in portable devices, power stations and automobiles. HOR like other redox reactions is kinetically impossible without an electrocatalyst. Pt-based electrocatalysts are applied for this reaction. Limited resources of Pt and its high cost hindered its usage in fuel cells. Tafel, Heyrovsky and Volmer mechanisms are three reaction steps for HOR on the electrocatalysts surface [34]. Alcohols directly oxidize in DAFCs. This type of fuel cells is favorable as next power sources for consumer and portable electronics. In comparison with hydrogen, some alcohols with low molecular weight like ethanol, glycerol and methanol that are liquid at ambient temperature and pressure are easy to store and transport [35]. The wide application of DAFCs depends on electrocatalytic performance of catalyst. Pt-based electrocatalysts are used in DAFCs, but to reach acceptable power output, high lading of electrocatalyst is needed, leading to high cost. Therefore, AOR electrocatalysts are vital to decrease overall cost of DAFCs. The accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere has led to serious consequences such as the greenhouse effect, climate change, and destructive environmental consequences. The use of CO2 as a massive and low-cost carbon source plays a key role in environmental protection measures. CO2 adsorption and storage have gained increasing popularity as they can provide a pathway for the conversion of CO2 into valuable hydrocarbon fuels such as methanol, formic acid, and methane [36,37]. CO2 activation is, however, a challenge and requires harsh conditions such as high energy and high pressure. CO2 conversion has been performed through various photochemical, biological, chemical, and electrochemical methods, among which, electrochemical approaches have shown several advantages [38–41]. In the electrochemical method, the reactions are performed by electrocatalysts at room temperature and can be directly controlled by controlling applied potential. Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) requires high amounts of energy for activation of a stable CO2 molecule to form an effective interaction with the catalyst surface. Upon the establishment of this effective interaction, other stages can proceed at mild conditions. Environmental pollution is imminent due to the excessive consumption of fossil fuels, necessitating the studies in search for clean alternatives to fossil fuels [42]. Hydrogen is an abundant and clean source of energy, causing no pollution. Water splitting is the most common method of hydrogen production [43]. Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occurs in the anode during the splitting of water. This reaction has slow kinetics and requires a high potential (1.23 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)), posing a serious constraint on large-scale hydrogen production. Urea-based energy conversion technology is also proposed as urea oxidation reaction (UOR) requires a much lower potential compared to OER (0.37 V vs. RHE) [44]. On the other hand, the urea content of urine can be converted to nitrogen and ammonia-containing compounds which can pollute water. Electrolysis of urea can remove these pollutants as it only produces non-toxic products such as CO2, N2, and H2 [45,46]. The urea electrolysis requires lower energy for hydrogen production due to its smaller theoretical overall voltage. The electrolyzer safety in the UOR method is ensured by avoiding the production of O2 and mixing O2 with H2. Through this method, harmful nitrogen-containing compounds of the water can be remediated. Therefore, finding efficient UOR electrocatalysts can decline the cost of anodic half-reaction by replacing UOR with OER while accelerating the hydrogen generation. NH3 is an essential chemical substance in the synthesis of chemical fertilizers; it also plays a decisive role in transportation and energy carrier in different fields including textile, agricultural and pharmaceutical. This important substance can be synthesized by three methods of Haber-Bosch method, azotobacter nitrogen fixation, and electrocatalysis [47,48]. Nitrogenase enzymes stabilize N2 under mild conditions in nature. This method is, however, very slow, limiting its practical applications. The industrial method of NH3 production, i.e. Haber-Bosch method, is performed at high temperatures and pressures by catalysts containing iron or ruthenium, which requires high levels of fossil fuels, leading to the release of several million tons of CO2 per year. Therefore, replacing low-cost, environmentally friendly methods with lower energy consumption and minimal environmental pollution is crucial for the production of NH3. Electrochemical N2 reduction could be a promising solution [49]. In this method, carbon-free and clean NH3 can be achieved under mild conditions using wind and solar energies. An important aspect of this method is to choose a proper electrocatalyst. Glucose is one of the most important compounds in the blood and food industry whose oxidation reaction has recently attracted the attention of many researchers. This compound is also applied as an energy source in many organisms, from bacteria to humans. Electrochemical glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) plays a key role in glucose electrochemical sensors and direct glucose fuel cell (DGFC) [50]. Glocuse sensing is highly important in the screening of environment, safety production of food, and medical diagnosis [51]. A variety of methods such as surface Plasmon resonance, optical, fluorescent, and electrochemical methods have been developed for glucose determination. Among these methods, electrochemical sensors are an ideal option due to their simplicity, high sensitivity, and fast response. Non-enzymatic glucose sensing and glucose oxidase-based sensing can be used in the electrochemical method. Amperometric biosensors use glucose oxidase (GO x ) bio-enzyme for glucose detection with higher selectivity compared to glucose. This method, however, suffers from several drawbacks such as GO x instability and susceptibility to toxic chemicals, temperature, pH, and humidity. The high price of GO x also limits the use of biosensors [52]. Therefore, using non-enzymatic sensors through electrocatalytic reaction on the surface of the electrode has attracted the attention of researchers due to its advantages such as reproducibility, stability, and simplicity. 3 MOFs as electrocatalysts for energy-related oxidation and reduction reactions One of the most essential concerns for constructing a sustainable and modern civilization is the energy supply, which is especially relevant now that we are confronting an increasing reduction in fossil resources, climate change, and population expansion in society. As a result, many attempts have been undertaken over the past decades to identify better solutions to address energy needs in industrial and academic areas [53,54]. In addition to energy supply, sophisticated systems for energy conversion and storage in large scale are critical. MABs, fuel cells, and CO2 reduction have all played important roles in energy development, and there is still promise for these technologies due to their portability and great energy efficiency in energy storage and conversion [55–57]. Oxidation and reduction reactions such as ORR, HOR, AOR, UOR, and CO2RR are encountered in these electrochemical systems for energy storage and conversion. Because of the slow kinetics of these processes, the role of electrocatalysts becomes increasingly colorful. As a result, the right selection of electrocatalysts is critical for the development of these technologies, as it allows for large-scale practical applications of these technologies [58]. 3.1 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) The ORR is a critical half-reaction in electrochemical energy conversion technologies such DAFCs, rechargeable MABs, and PEMFCs (Fig. 3 ). This half reaction is carried out in acidic and basic liquids using Eqs. (1)–(6) [59]. (1) Acidic medium Direct pathway: (1) O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - → 2 H 2 O E ° = 1.230 V Series pathways: (2) O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 O 2 E ° = 0.695 V (3) H 2 O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - → 2 H 2 O E ° = 1.230 V (2) Alkaline medium Direct pathway: (4) O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - → 4 O H - E ° = 1.230 V Series pathways: (5) O 2 + H 2 O + 2 e - → H 2 O - + O H - E ° = 0.695 V (6) H O 2 - + H 2 O + 2 e - → 3 O H - E ° = 1.230 V According to these equations, two pathways can be used to accomplish this half-reaction: two-electron and four-electron pathways, which are used because the four-electron method has a faster reaction speed. Pt-based electrocatalysts are still used as excellent ORR electrocatalysts in practical applications nowadays. These materials, however, have constraints such as high cost and scarcity, which has led to substantial research and search for materials with plentiful, stable, and low-cost supplies. Because of its unique qualities such as well-defined metal nodes, tunable pore diameters, and programmable chemical components, MOFs as a class of porous materials have won the competition with other materials as electrocatalysts [60–62]. Conductive MOFs are a class of MOFs with good electrocatalytic performance. The delocalization of electrons in the framework through the covalent bonding between metal and organic linkers creates high conductivity. ORR performance of a conductive MOF with 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene (HITP) ligand tested by Dinca's group without any modifications or post-synthesis [63]. The existence of porosity channels in the structure of MOF-based electrocatalysts, together with accessible redox sites, enables for better and greater usage of sites for redox reactions as compared to other heterogeneous catalysts. Porosity and accessibility of redox sites help to ion and electron transfers during electrocatalytic reaction. Tuning the pore structure and accessibility of redox active sites prove the structure–property of MOF-based electrocatalysts and can guide the design and optimize MOF-based electrocatalysts to improve performance. Despite these benefits, these materials have drawbacks such as limited electrical conductivity and chemical stability. Combining MOFs with other functional materials, such as carbon or inorganic compounds, is one strategy to boost their electrocatalytic efficiency [64,65]. Obtaining MOF composites can overcome their drawbacks and improve their electrocatalytic activity. MOF composites typically exhibit good electrical conductivity and high surface area due to structural benefits. The complexes of metal porphyrin are suitable electrocatalyst due to their rich chemistry and ability to catalyze a large number of reactions [66,67]. Particularly, Fe(III) porphyrins have been introduces an efficient electrocatalyst for ORR. These classes of complexes are associated with hemoproteins structure and establish a strong interaction with oxygen molecules [68]. Various MOFs containing of Fe(III) porphyrin have been reported, particularly porous coordination network-222 (PCN-222) has been used as a catalyst for ORR [69]. The advantages of this class of complexes as electrocatalyst include high density of available catalytic sites, structural and chemical stability, and immobilization of the electrocatalyst within the structure of MOF [70]. Available electroactive sites make easy electron and ion transfers between the electrolyte solution and the surface electrode. The structure–property relationship has given this performance to the electrocatalyst and this can be a template to tune the structure to improve the property. In a report, Usov et al. introduced a robust MOF, PCN-223-Fe(Zr6O4(OH)4(Fe(III)-(TCCP)3 containing Fe(III) porphyrin linkers and Zr6 oxo cluster nodes are employed as an electrocatalyst for ORR [71]. The structure of this MOF includes large triangular channels with high surface area and permanent porosity, making fast diffusion of product and substrate inside the framework (Fig. 4 a(i, ii)) [72]. Structure stability is due to the links between the porphyrin linkers and clusters of Zr6 in the structure, making it appropriate as an electrocatalyst for ORR in acidic environment. The electrochemical studies show that PCN-223-Fe has presented a redox wave in normal hydrogen electrode (NHE vs. −0.5 V), which is due to Fe(III)TCPP/Fe(II)TCPP process. Also, examining the effect of proton source on PCN-223-Fe film showed high selectivity of H2O/H2O2 (Fig. 4a(iii–v)). Because of their wide planar networks in two dimensions with weak out-of-plane π-π stacking and entirely in-plane π-delocalization, conductive two-dimensional (2D) conjugated MOFs are very important as electrocatalysts. These MOFs have an increased electron transfer capacity due to their 2D structure and the ability to utilize active sites, in addition to their inherent benefits for usage as electrocatalysts. More importantly, these MOFs provide a solid foundation for determining and researching the ORR mechanism. With this in mind, Zhong et al. published a work in which they reported a layered 2D conjugated MOF with Co complexes as linkage [73]. 2D conjugated structure, specific electronic configuration of Co-O centers, and ordered porous framework are the reasons for this structure's superiority as an electrocatalyst for ORR. This is also another witness to prove structure–property relationship and assists to introduce next electrocatalysts with improved performance. MOF was combined with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) to increase its conductivity. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed in alkaline solution to evaluate the performance of ORR, PcCu-O8-Co/CNT, and when the electrolyte solution was saturated with oxygen, a cathodic peak at E 1/2 = 0.83 V vs. RHE was observed due to the excellent performance of the electrocatalyst ORR (n = 3.93, j L = 5.3 mA cm−2). Furthermore, according to density functional theory (DFT) analyses, Co-O units in the structure were designated as active sites for ORR (Fig. 4b(i–iv)). Atomically dispersed metal sites are of significant interest in the field of electrocatalysts, and MOF-based single site electrocatalysts provide them with unique features compared to other materials due to benefits such as well-assembled organic ligands and inorganic nodes in MOF structure [74]. Due to the structure–property relationship, the MOF structure's adjustability, orderliness, and availability of pores promote mass transport for electrolyte ions and reactants during electrochemical reactions, and the presence of single sites in MOFs facilitates electronic structure regulation and electrocatalytic mechanism discovery [75–77]. Despite the mentioned benefits, the development of single sites in MOFs for electrochemical applications is limited site blockage due to the presence of organic ligands in the MOF structure, low conductivity, and the kinetic barriers [78,79]. As the electrocatalytic performance of single site MOFs is closely related to accessibility of the single sites and charge and mass transports, a method should be explored to increase their performance for diverse electrocatalytic reactions. Doping MOFs with conductive materials such as carbon materials is another technique to boost their electrocatalytic activity by adjusting building blocks in MOFs to establish channels for charge and mass transfers. Ma et al., for example, reported on the electrocatalytic performance of atomically dispersed active sites in Co-MOFs employing various carbon substrates for ORR [77]. The results of this group revealed that the growth of MOFs on carbon supports was done in different orientations, resulting in different electronic effects in them and affecting the performance of the electrocatalyst for ORR. Because of the semiconductivity of the MOF, electron transmission from CNTs to active sites is somewhat hampered, but when reduced graphene oxide (rGO) is utilized, electron transitions owing to π-π stacking between porphyrin and graphene are enabled. The performance of the Co-MOF@rGO electrocatalyst for ORR was superior to that of the Co-MOF@CNTs. A reduction mechanism for Co-MOF@rGO was identified and two reduction pathways for determined for Co-MOF@CNTs (Fig. 5 a(i)). Researchers have proposed numerous routes to improve the conductivity of MOFs. The main focus is on the design and fabrication of carbon-based electrocatalysts for ORR. Carbon materials not only improve the conductivity, but they also prevent the aggregation of active components making a huge space available for electrocatalyst function. In this regard, N,S-doped rGO was utilized in a study to improve the conductivity of Cu-MOF. N,S-doped rGO possesses high conductivity and can form a composite with improved conductivity upon linking with MOF structure. In such structures, electron transfer can be performed at an ideal rate, leading to high electrocatalytic performance. Improved conductivity of this composite electrocatalyst has boosted its performance. Indeed, ion and mass transfers that have so important role in electrocatalytic reactions have improved. In the mentioned research, electrochemical ORR tests were carried out in an alkaline solution and the NS-rGO-Cu-MOF 8% exhibited the best performance with an onset potential of −0.06 V. In this report, metal-free N,S-doped rGO resulted in a satisfactory enhancement of MOF conductivity [80]. In another study, CoZn- zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIF)/carbon spheres (CS) (CoZn-ZIF/CS) were explored for the ORR in an electrolyte (0.1 M KOH) [81]. The results indicated that the porosity and high degree graphitization of the structure can improve the conductivity and mass transport, thus, enhancing the ORR performance and structure–property relationship has been revealed. Based on CV curves, the oxygen reduction peak of the electrocatalyst emerged at 0.83 V. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves also revealed 5.11 mV cm−2 at 0.2 V vs. RHE diffusion-limited current density, suggesting proper ORR performance of the electrocatalyst. In another study, Jahan et al. reported an rGO-porphyrin MOF composite with increased porosity and charge transfer rate possessing proper performance in four-electron ORR. In the mentioned composite, the oxygenated functional group on rGO served as an electron transfer mediator which facilitated the ORR performance [82]. Three-dimensional (3D) N-doped transition metal carbon materials can be effective in electrochemical applications for oxygen electrochemical studies due to their low cost and high surface area, i.e. effective properties for ion/electron transfer. For instance, a 3D porous structure with nitrogen-coordinated Fe centers can be a major active site for ORR [83]. The synergistic effect between 3D structure and metal species can be effective in the charge density of active sites. Najam et al. utilized ZIF-8 as a precursor to obtain 3D-Fe-NC followed by p-doping to improve electrocatalyst performance. The results of this study showed optimal ORR performance of 3D-Fe-PNC [84]. In a novel strategy to enhance the ORR performance, large pore MOF-derivative material was employed whose surface defects were adjusted by KOH [85]. In this work, ZIF-8 was used as a precursor. The results indicated that the use of KOH not only affects the pore size but also effectively contributes to the creation of defects in MOF-derived nanomaterials and activated the active sites to improve mass transfer, therefore affecting the ORR reactions. In an effort to find ideal high-performance electrocatalysts for electrochemical reactions, one case involved the formation of bimetallic or trimetallic alloys using Pt and 3d transition metals to accelerate ORR [86,87]. Xiong et al. applied MOF as a precursor for PtCo-bimetallic electrocatalyst for ORR. The synergistic effect between PtCo and Pt-N-C was effective in accelerating ORR. On the other hand, Pt-rich shell with two atomic layers and the formation of PtCo@Pt core/shell was effective [88]. 3.2 Alcohol oxidation reaction (AOR) In fuel cell electrochemical devices, without high temperature, low cost, high efficiency and without pollution, chemical energy is converted to electrical energy [89–91]. Among fuel cells, DAFCs have attracted attentions. The importance of this type of fuel cells stems from the high energy density of alcohols, as well as their environmental friendliness, portability, and low cost. Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) are one of the most extensively utilized fuel cells in the United States and Europe. Methanol is oxidized at the anode to CO2 and H2O and oxygen is reduced at the cathode to H2O (Fig. 6 ). Methanol fuel offers numerous advantages, including the fact that it is liquid, which allows it to be transported, stored, and circulated throughout the fuel network. It also is an inexpensive fuel and its oxidation products are CO2 and H2O. Because DMFCs function at temperatures below 150 °C, NO x is not produced; methanol is acid resistant; and using methanol as an electrochemically active fuel simplifies engineering challenges and decreases costs. Despite these benefits, there are a number of issues that must be addressed. Membrane thickness, construction of the membrane electrode, loading of the catalyst, and, most critically, the slow pace of cathode and anode reactions are all issues in managing water and heat and ensuring stability throughout operation. Many investigations are being undertaken by researchers to introduce and identify electrocatalysts with low cost and high performance in order to address these challenges. Commercially available DMFC catalysts are Pt-based electrocatalysts, which create byproduct carbon monoxide, which prevents active sites from reacting. As a result, Pt-based electrocatalysts are alloyed with other metals in order to prevent the generation of byproduct carbon monoxide and the formation of CO2 [92,93]. However, high cost of the noble metal-based materials challenges employing these materials in large scale and searching for materials based on non-noble metals becomes very important [94]. The direct application of MOFs as electrocatalysts in electrocatalytic reactions, including MOR, is extremely rare. In one study, for example, a Ni-MOF-74/CPE electrode was used as an electrocatalyst for MOR in an alkaline electrolyte, and its performance for MOR was investigated [95]. The results revealed that this electrocatalyst was stable under experimental circumstances for MOR, and that the overpotential reaction was decreased, as well as overcoming the slow reaction kinetics in alkaline solution. Among the approaches suggested for finding efficient electrocatalysts to replace precious metal-based electrocatalysts, developing MOF heterocomposites can be mentioned [96–100]. They not only have the intrinsic features of MOFs, but they also have good electrical stability and conductivity, making them intriguing alternatives to precious noble-metal electrocatalysts. Although these types of composites exhibit improved electrical conductivity and a synergistic effect between active sites and increased active sites, the main challenge of proper two-phase integration in increasing the stability and improving the performance of the composite material remains a challenge that requires additional research in this context. In one investigation, Liu et al. synthesized and employed hierarchically structured Ni-MOF on the Ni(OH)2 heterocomposite (Ni-Ni) for MOR [101]. By developing a hierarchical structure with synergistic effects, the availability of additional active sites promotes ion penetration; boosts electrical conductivity, hence, providing outstanding MOR performance. An increase in the surface area of composite contributes to the role of Ni-MOF and boosts the electrocatalytic activity of the composite. The Ni-2 hydrangea is equally coated with Ni nanorods, as revealed in the Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images in Fig. 7 (a)(i–iv). This structure makes proper use of the catalytic roles of Ni and Ni-2. CV curves for samples in 1 M MeOH + 0.1 M KOH solution reveal that the Ni-Ni-2 electrocatalyst (24.6 mA cm−2) performs better for MOR (Fig. 7a(v, vi)). Because of its economic, technical, and environmental sustainability, biodiesel has received a lot of attention as a renewable biofuel. Biodiesel is produced by performing a transesterification reaction on vegetable oils or animal fats. Biodiesel is non-toxic and reduces hydrocarbon emissions and hazardous wastes; these make biodiesel extremely valuable from an environmental standpoint. Glycerol is one of the byproducts of this reaction. Glycerol is a raw material that is widely used in industries such as food and pharmaceuticals. Given that the widespread production of biodiesel, the supply of glycerol exceeds the demand for it, prompting researchers to consider more efficient uses of glycerol [102]. The electrooxidation of glycerol is an appealing and practical method for converting it into valuable products. According to the literature, partial oxidation of glycerol in alkaline solutions yields a number of products, some of which are useful in industry [103]. In DAFCs, the glycerol oxidation reaction (GOR) generates valuable products as well as electrical energy. Recent research has revealed that the catalysts used for GOR are noble metals such as Pd and Pt, but their selectivity to obtain the desired products is lower, highlighting the need for more efficient electrocatalysts. The products of this reaction are identified using chronoamperometry in conjunction with LSV [104–106]. According to a report, CoCu-MOF/PANI, synthesized by the hydrothermal method, has demonstrated excellent performance as an electrocatalyst for GOR. According to the report, the largest CV area belonged to CoCu-MOF/PANI in a three-electrode system in 0.5 M KOH + 0.5 M glycerol electrolyte solution, indicating good performance of this electrocatalyst for GOR, and this electrocatalyst also showed the highest current density. The improved conductivity in the composite due to the presence of PANI, and, of course, the synergistic effect in the electrocatalyst, have been reported as reasons for this excellent performance (Fig. 7b(i–v)) [107]. MOFs are excellent candidates for use as precursors in the preparation of heteroatom doped carbon compounds [108]. In this field, ZIFs are more essential as precursors containing carbon and nitrogen species with a distinctive porous structure [109,110]. Doping of heteroatom in the electrocatalyst changes density of electron, and charge polarization, enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of MOF-derived materials and conductivity [108]. The presence of a hierarchically porous structure in N-doped CNT-based hybrids based on ZIFs enhances transport of mass and is extremely effective for increasing electrocatalytic performance. However, the reduction of nitrogen at high temperatures of pyrolysis limits the electrocatalytic efficiency in this scenario. Because low nitrogen concentration in N-doped carbon materials derived from MOFs limits their electrocatalytic efficiency, nitrogen content control by high-temperature pyrolysis is critical. The networks of mesopores in mesoporous carbons are excellent for electron and mass transportation. Based on structure–property relationship, the incorporation of nitrogen into the structure of mesoporous carbon results in the formation of active sites, which improves the electrocatalyst performance for MOR. Based on this knowledge, Zhang et al. proposed MOF-derived N-doped nanotube decorated mesoporous carbon (Pt/Co@NCNTs-MC) as an electrocatalyst for MOR [111]. They employed N-rich melamine at appropriate temperatures and times to alter the proportion of nitrogen in this electrocatalyst (Fig. 8 a). During the pyrolysis process, melamine reacts with cobalt to generate Co-N x bonds and N-doped CNTs, resulting in a large number of active sites in the electrocatalyst. N-doped-CNTs have a large surface area and allow for mass and electron transfer. According to the researchers, the synthesized electrocatalyst has demonstrated good MOR performance as well as great stability. The CV curves displayed in Fig. 8(b and c) correspond to methanol oxidation peaks at 0.7 V and residual carbon species oxidation peaks at 0.45 V [112,113]. The results indicate that mass activity for Pt/Co@NCNTs-MC800-4 is maximum. The performance of DMFCs heavily depends on the anode catalyst. So far, Pt was the most common electrocatalyst utilized in DMFCs due to its stability and electrocatalytic effectiveness. Nevertheless, its commercial application is limited due to several factors, including its high cost. Moreover, Pt is prone to poisoning by CO-like species during MOR, which can substantially limit its performance. Third, intermediates are adsorbed on the surface of Pt during MOR, impairing the reaction's kinetics, restricting the use of Pt. As a result, treatments such as lowering Pt loading can be effective. As a result, researchers have been exploring for alloying of Pt metal with some transition metals and have conducted several studies and researches in this field, with research findings indicating that Pt-M alloy electrocatalysts have greatly increased MOR performance [114,115]. Electrocatalysts with a core–shell structure were considered in this example. As a result, non-precious metals are used as the core, with Pt metal serving as the shell [116]. Long et al. (2020) used a Cu@Pt/C core–shell structure as the electrocatalyst for MOR, which was synthesized using Cu-MOF as a precursor [60]. Long's group investigated the MOR performance of Cu@Pt/C electrocatalyst in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.5 M MeOH electrolyte solutions. I b is the reverse anodic peak current associated with freshly chemisorbed species oxidation, i.e., the oxidation of newly adsorbed MeOH, from an electrochemical standpoint. The electrocatalysts presented in this work shown good stability for MOR and low Pt dose, but they were competitive with commercial Pt/C samples, and this behavior was attributable to the electronic effect between Pt, Cu, and electrochemical surface area. Different types of nanoporous carbon materials play a key role in energy storage/conversion and catalyst due to their unique properties such as high surface area, excellent chemical stability, and high conductivity [117]. On the other hand, doping of these carbon materials with heteroatoms has a double effect on their electrochemical performance and can dramatically improve the mass transfer. This knowledge was sufficient for Wu et al. to assess the MOR using a Cu-MOF (Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST-1)) [118]. In their study, they first obtained nanoporous carbon materials with hierarchical pores using HKUST-1; then, they attained Ni/NPC and Pt/NPC using chloroplatinic acid, nickel nitrate, and hydrochloric acid and studied its performance for MOR. Pt/NPC-900 outperformed commercial Pt/C for MOR in terms of poison resistance and current density. 3.3 Hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) Hydrogen (H2) has been examined in the past decades as a source of clean energy [119,120]. PEMFCs technology uses H2 as a fuel, to electrochemically convert chemical energy into electrical at high efficiency with no pollution. The advantages of PEMFCs such as high power density, low emissions and high efficiency have promoted its applications in portable power devices, automotive engines, and stationary power generation stations [121,122]. Due to success of this technology especially in automotive applications, its commercialization is of great importance. PEMFCs performance includes two half-reactions that occur in ORR cathode and HOR anode (Fig. 9 ). Most applied catalysts for both half reactions are Pt-based materials that are costly. Thus, in recent years, studies have been done to find alternative catalysts for commercial applications with desired performance, high stability, and low cost. However, design and development of electrocatalysts with high performance for ORR is more important than HOR due to its slow kinetics, but performance and slow kinetics of HOR in alkaline environment degrades total performance of fuel cells compared to acidic environment. Thus, finding efficient electrocatalysts for HOR in alkaline environments is essential [123,124]. The elementary process for HOR in alkaline environment is performed according to reactions (7) to (9); according to these reactions, H2 is oxidized to H2O according to the Tafel-Volmer and Heyrovsky-Volmer mechanisms [123,125–128]. (7) T a f e l : H 2 + 2 ∗ ↔ 2 H ∗ (8) H e y r o v s k y : H 2 + OH - + ∗ ↔ H ∗ + H 2 O + e - (9) V o l m e r : H ∗ + OH - ↔ ∗ + H 2 O + e - The usage of stable biopolymer MOF as an electrocatalyst for HOR was discussed in an intriguing report published in 2019 by Kadirov group [129]. Because of its jelly qualities, pectin has already shown promising industrial applications. MOF with divalent transition metal ions generates a spatial network with a carbohydrate chain of pectin that is difficult to dissolve in water. The creation of this class of MOFs will pave the way for non-platinum group metal electrocatalysts for PEMFCs. In this study, an electrocatalyst based on Ni-based pectin MOF was investigated. The electrocatalyst's maximum power density and maximum current density were 1.5 mW cm−2 and 5.2 mA cm−2, respectively. Yang et al. used a Ni-MOF as a precursor to create a porous, high-conductivity Ni/NiO/C electrocatalyst (Fig. 10 a). Owing to the modular and programmable character of MOFs, the developed electrocatalyst demonstrated good HOR performance in alkaline solution with almost nearly zero onset potential [130]. According to the results, Ni/NiO/C-700 exhibited the highest current density among the other samples, due to the production of an optimal ratio of Ni(0):Ni(II) and the formation of interfacial sites between Ni and NiO, both of which playing an important role in the improvement of the performance. CO tolerance and long-term stability are two essential factors that determine the performance of a HOR electrocatalyst in practical applications. The anodic current density of this electrocatalyst is lower than that of the commercial model Pt for HOR (Fig. 10b). According to this report, Ni/NiO/C-700 can be an appropriate electrocatalyst for H2 fuel cell applications due to its good stability and CO tolerance. Some reports indicate that reduced loading of Pd electrocatalysts on carbon supports have shown better performance for HOR compared to Pt-based electrocatalysts [131]. On the other hand, results of searching for electrocatalysts for HOR in the literature demonstrates that there are a limited number of reports in which MOFs are used as a template to obtain carbon for Pd-based electrocatalyst materials derived from MOFs. Metal/carbon composites synthesized as template have features like controllable morphology, high surface area, improved electrical conductivity, high porosity [132,133]. Thus, MOFs are used as templates for providing MOF-derived carbons with excellent features and performance for energy applications [134,135]. According to this knowledge, in a report published by Ipadeola et al., Pd nanostructured supported on Ni-deficient (Ni-d) and Ni-rich (Ni-r) MOF derived carbon (MOFDC) has been examined to study the HOR behavior [136]. According to the results of this group, Pd/Ni-d/MOFDC has shown better HOR behavior. Also, theoretical investigations further revealed that the influence of defect chemistry of support was greater on HOR performance than high Ni concentration. According to the findings, the Ni-rich electrocatalyst in this research has Ni(OH)2 interfaces, which are an impediment to HOR performance, whereas the removal of this interface in the Ni-deficient sample is an advantage for better HOR performance. 3.4 Urea oxidation reaction (UOR) In addition to renewable energy sources like solar, wind and etc., hydrogen fuel is an excellent alternative to fossil fuels due to its environmental friendliness and high energy density. Development in the context of employing hydrogen as fuel requires operating efficiency, therefore energy conversion techniques such as water splitting and hydrogen fuel cells are used [137–139]. As a result, there are issues and restrictions in terms of cost and practical operations in the operational phase of using hydrogen as a fuel. As a result of these limits, researchers are looking for more cost-effective methods of manufacturing hydrogen and fuel cells. In comparison to hydrogen fuel, which is a clean fuel, urea comes from a dirty source, such as animal and human urine (Fig. 11 ). However, urea-based energy conversion techniques such as direct urea fuel cells, urea electrolysis, and photo-electrochemical urea splitting outperform hydrogen-based energy conversion approaches. In comparison to hydrogen, urea is more common in nature and more readily available as a fuel. Furthermore, human urine is a source of urea, which is produced in enormous quantities on a regular basis. Direct urea fuel cells, like hydrogen fuel cells, require a comparable voltage of 1.15 V compared to hydrogen fuel cells that require a voltage of 1.23 V [140,141]. Improper agricultural fertilizer use, as well as non-standard industrial waste management, will result in unregulated urea in nature, resulting in water and soil pollution. Urea pollution in the ocean has been linked to the development of harmful Domoic acid. In urea fuel cell, urea is oxidized to generate electricity, H2O, CO2 and N2. To perform oxidation reactions oxygen molecules are needed. Reduction of water produces hydroxyl ions that react with urea and release electrons and help to produce the electricity. In urea electrolysis, by imputing electrical energy, urea molecules are dissociated and hydrogen is produced through water hydrolysis. Also, to perform reaction in urea electrolysis, only 0.37 V is required that is much lower than water splitting that requires 1.23 V [142]. The UOR which is the foundation of urea-based technology is the focus of this review and section. Urea in urine is transformed to nitrogen-containing compounds and ammonia, posing a risk of contamination of water and soil. However, urea electrolysis yields the non-toxic chemicals H2, CO2, and N2 specified in Eqs. (10)–(12). (10) CO(NH2)2 + 6OH- → CO2 + N2 + 5H2O + 6e− E° = −0.46 V (11) 6H2O + 6e−→ 3H2 + 6OH− E° = −0.83 V (12) CO(NH2)2 + H2O → CO2 + N2 + 3H2 E° = 0.37 V As demonstrated by these reactions, UOR is significant for two reasons: increasing hydrogen production and reducing environmental pollution [108,141,143,144]. Precious metal-based catalysts are employed in urea-based technologies like hydrogen research. To overcome such difficulties, the search and development of efficient low-cost electrocatalysts is a priority in this scenario. High oxidation states can be feasibly achieved in metal ions of MOFs Due to their strong interaction with ligands. As a result of the unique features and adjustable structures in 2D MOFs, metal ions can achieve high oxidation states and promise to execute electrocatalytic reactions such as UOR. Zhu's group reported a 2D MOF with high oxidation states for Ni in a composite comprising Ni ions and benzendicarboxylic acid ligands [145]. High oxidation states for Ni exist in this structure due to the strong interaction between Ni ions and ligands. Because of the existence of Ni ions with high oxidation states and the presence of many active sites in the structure, the UOR performance of these 2D Ni-MOF nanosheets has been found to be quite good. Because the concentration of urea in human urine is 0.33 M, this group employed 0.33 M urea in UOR testing as well [146]. According to the results of the sample's OER behavior at 1 M KOH, an oxidation peak was seen, which was attributable to the creation of NiOOH. The anodic current density rose after adding urea to the electrolyte solution, and the onset potential was extremely close to NiOOH. In terms of practical applications, although MOFs feature unsaturated coordination sites, poor contact between guest molecules and nodes occurs due to the presence of organic linkers in the structure of MOFs [147,148]. Previously used calcination procedures were unable to address this critical and vital necessity. Until Tsumori introduced quasi-MOFs, those are intermediate between MOFs and metal oxides. Thermal conversion approaches are used to eliminate certain organic ligands and create quasi-MOFs. In contrast to MOF/metal or metal oxide/metal structures that are the product of pyrolysis, quasi-MOF/metal oxide composites improve the performance of the electrocatalyst. When exposed to guest molecules, this generates interaction, which increases electrocatalyst behavior dramatically [149]. This discovery has the potential to be extremely useful for executing electrocatalytic processes such as UOR. Hence, Cheng et al. transformed Ce-MOF to quasi-MOF by direct heating in the presence of a nitrogen atmosphere and after calcination, the structure and porosity of the raw material are conserved, and many active sites are created. As a result, this group reported its UOR performance [44]. UOR behavior was studied in a 1 M KOH + 0.33 M urea electrolyte solution. The LSV curves for the samples obtained at different calcination temperatures revealed that the Ce-MOF-350 with the lowest overpotential sample had the best UOR performance. The structure and porosity of the MOF are intact at this calcination temperature, and there are many active sites available. Electroactive metal centers for electrochemical reactions at unsaturated sites are at the electrocatalytic surface in the Ce-MOF structure with straw bundle-like morphology. This structure's distinct architecture provides pathways for ionic transduction as well as a large surface area for the electrocatalyst that shows the importance of structure–property relationship to improve behavior. The presence of Ce (IV) ions and their conversion to Ce (III) ions improves conductivity in this sample. Furthermore, the existence of assembled nanorods as a straw bundle structure justifies the electrocatalytic stability to execute UOR by increasing the number of active sites due to oxygen vacancies (Fig. 12 a(i–iv)). Nanowires, which have a low dimensional structure and are rich in active metal sites, play a significant role in electrocatalysis. MOFs with nanowire morphology preserve their bulk properties, and their electrocatalytic activity becomes increasingly critical when more metal sites are added to their surface. In this instance, instead of being positioned on the surface of the MOF channels, the active sites within them will have a considerably higher impact on electrocatalytic activities [150–152]. Yuan et al. evaluated Ni-MOFs in different dimensions and investigated the relationship between structure and electrocatalytic performance for UOR. Their research revealed that Ni-MOF nanowires had the lowest overpotential and maximum stability for UOR, while neuron-like and nanosphere morphologies performed worse. Because this morphology has more Ni atoms available as active sites on the electrode surface and has a high conductivity, it is said to be excellent for UOR (Fig. 12b(i, ii)) [153]. The significant progress in urea-based technologies requires a great understanding of the obstacles and their solutions. UOR suffers from some limitations such as the lab-scale technologies to create UOR catalysts, and significant cost issues in the mass production. Poor catalyst performance is unlikely upon mass production of catalysts by laboratory procedures. Moreover, studies on UOR are not based on the purposeful design of catalysts and the characteristics of the urea molecule, hindering the exploitation and development of this sector. Thanks to their unique features such as ultrathin thickness, 2D nanosheets have gained the attention of researchers in the field of catalysts. Their large surface area offers more active sites for electrocatalysts, facilitating charge transfer and mass transport, eventually improving the catalyst performance. For instance, Xu research team (2020) solvothermally synthesized Ir-doped Ni-MOF nanosheets to assess UOR [154]. LSV curves in electrolyte (1 M KOH) in the presence of urea showed an onset potential of 1.32 V vs. RHE, confirming the formation of NiIII-OOH species as UOR active sites (Fig. 12c(i, ii)). Wang et al. succeeded in direct phosphidation of MOF to reach Ni2P@Ni-MOF nanosheets whose UOR performance was assessed [155]. The results indicated the proper performance of this electrocatalyst as it only required 141 V vs. RHE at the current density of 100 mA cm−2. Room temperature-synthesized Ni-MOF was utilized as an electrocatalyst for UOR in alkaline solution which showed 1.34 V vs. RHE onset potential [156]. In the mentioned work, carbon paper was utilized to prepare electrodes which had a significant impact on the improvement of conductivity and UOR performance. In a study conducted by Xu et al. in 2020, Co(OH)2 was applied as a template to grow MOF through a gas phase method. A part of Co-MOF was converted into CoS x upon vulcanization [45]. Noteworthy, MOF grown on the Ni foam established better contact with the electrolyte as compared with the powder samples. Moreover, urchin-like morphology in this MOF enhances the surface area and thus increased the electrochemically active sites. Therefore, in the presence of 0.5 M urea, CoS x /Co-MOF in 1 M KOH only required 1.48 V vs. RHE for overall UOR at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. Based on Zhang et al., FeNi-MOF nanosheets were obtained upon Fe doping in the Ni-MOF structure through the hydrothermal method. An improvement was observed in UOR performance as Fe-doping affected the electronic structure of MOF and formed more active sites for UOR. The cell voltage of 1.43 V and proper stability were also reported in this research [157]. The formation of a hierarchical structure could be an efficient approach to increase the synergistic effects in MOFs and tune their structure. In other words, the performance of the electrocatalyst will be improved upon the formation of hierarchical nanocomposites due to the increase in active sites and mass transport as well as declined charge transfer distance. In this regard, Li et al. synthesized the Ni-MOF@NiO-Ni composite through a solvothermal method. The interesting point of this research was the upholding role of NiO/Ni nanorods in the reaction and the partial conversion of Ni-MOF nanosheets to nanorods. Such nanosheet/nanorod composite improved stability and lead to uniform distribution of the active sites. Using the various morphologies of Ni-based materials, this electrocatalyst exhibited superior UOR behavior with a cell voltage of 1.42 V and considerable stability [158]. Metallocene introduction into MOF structure could be a strategy to improve the electrocatalytic performance of MOFs due to increased stability, improved conductivity, and facilitated charge transfer during the catalytic reactions. Li et al. hydrothermally synthesized Ferrocene-NiCo-MOF and evaluated its UOR performance in 1 M KOH in the presence of 0.33 M urea [159]. Despite the frequent introduction and application of Ni-based materials in the field of electrocatalysts for oxidation and reduction reactions, here, Ni-MOFs were introduced. The electrocatalytic performance of these materials is still lower than the commercial samples, which is a huge challenge. Regarding the confirmed relationship of intermediate adsorption with the electronic structure of the active sites, the mentioned challenge could be resolved by modulating the Ni+3 species electronic structure to reach excellent UOR performance. Heteroatom incorporation could be an effective strategy. Gao et al. introduced a bimetallic MIL-53, Ni+3 electronic structures with better UOR performance compared to the monometallic samples. NiFe-MIL-53 exhibited the best UOR performance [160]. Knowing that MOF nanosheets can facilitate mass transport and make active sites more accessible, the conductivity of pristine MOFs can be improved by their hybridization with metal sulfides to further exploit these materials as an electrocatalyst. In a study by Li et al., NiCo-MOF nanosheet/NiS was synthesized by hydrothermal method to be used in UOR with proper performance and high stability which can be attributed to the electronic environment formed as a result of the synergistic effect of this structure [161]. Another important point is the extensive application of one-dimensional MOFs such as nanowires, nanobelts, and nanorods in diverse fields including catalysts that can be assigned to the unique anisotropy. For instance, thanks to their non-directionality and flexibility, nanobelts have a high surface area with numerous active sites, thus they could be an ideal candidate for electrocatalysis of diverse oxidation and reduction reactions including UOR. Accordingly, Ni-MIL-77 nanobelts were utilized in 2021 to assess their UOR performance [162]. In this structure, the active sites are Ni sites which are placed on the surface of the nanobelts. Such unsaturated sites on the electrode surface can accept electrons of the urea and promote the reaction toward the formation of CO2 and N2. The Xu research group employed Ni-MOF as a template in two steps, growing the Ni-Fe Prussian blue analogue on it, and finally performed a phosphating reaction, and Ni2P/Fe2P (denoted as MNPBA-P) were used as electrocatalysts for UOR (Fig. 13 a(i)) [163]. The use of Ni-MOF as a template in this work, as opposed to other templates, produces a reaction in milder conditions, resulting in a skeleton of carbon and the presence of Ni2P and Fe2P in the electrocatalyst, which increases the electrochemically active surface area and, as a result, conductivity. The conductivity of the sample improved after the phosphatization reaction, resulting in outstanding electrocatalytic behavior for the UOR (Fig. 13a(ii)). Ni3N has strong electrocatalytic performance and many active sites, and charge transfer is said to be facile in it, however its structure is usually unregulated [164,165]. According to the features of MOFs as precursors, it appears that MOF can be employed to generate Ni3N. Hu et al. developed and reported on Ni-MOF derived nickel nitride (C-350) as an effective bifunctional electrocatalyst for UOR and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) (Fig. 13b(i, ii)) [166]. 3.5 Carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) Carbon dioxide (CO2) is produced as a byproduct of industrial activity of human and hydrocarbon burning [167,168]. This greenhouse gas has a negative impact on the environment and is classified as a waste product. Because they absorb and re-emit sunlight infrared radiation, they cause the earth's temperature to rise, and because its production is growing, researchers' attention has been drawn to finding strategies to manage its amount in the atmosphere and cut CO2 emissions. CO2 can be used to produce essential chemical molecules, which can assist lower CO2 levels in the environment [169]. CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is a reaction in which CO2 is turned into useful chemicals and fuels, and it has received a lot of interest in recent years due to environmental issues and a lack of energy resources [170–172]. Researchers have shown great interests in the electrochemical CO2 reduction reactions as it is performed under mild conditions and at ambient temperature and pressure, which are valuable benefit in the application of this approach on a broad scale. Unlike the previous reactions, it is a complex multi-electron process that yields several products such as HCHO, CH4, HCOOH, CO, and CH3CH2OH (Fig. 14 ) [173]. Thus, CO2RR has a slow kinetics to achieve stable CO molecule. Different traditional catalysts have been utilized for this reaction resulting in diverse products. Despite extensive studies on CO2RR for decades, the development of an efficient electrocatalyst for CO2RR is still in its infancy, where a proper choice of electrocatalyst is of considerable difficulty. The electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction occurs at the cathode under an applied potential and produces useful products. However, it demands a lot of energy and competes with the hydrogen evaluation reaction (HER). As a result, it will be beneficial to seek for and employ electrocatalysts that demand less energy in order to beat HER. The ideal electrocatalyst should have a large current density, stability, and selectivity, and requires small applied voltage. MOFs, because of their porous structure and high surface area, can be an excellent choice for usage in CO2RR, as well as other electrocatalytic processes explored thus far. Furthermore, MOFs molecular control is accomplished without compromising catalytic performance, which is not achievable with other metal-based catalysts. More crucially, because MOFs have a high CO2 affinity, they accelerate catalytic performance in CO2RR while increasing CO2 concentrations around it [174]. Defects caused by amorphization appear to be more important than electrocatalyst porosity in obtaining MeOH via CO2RR, because CO2RR can be performed easily at the MOF level. Stolar et al. investigated this issue using a bimetallic MOF to perform CO2RR [175]. They studied CO2RR performance for c-ZnCu-MOF-74 crystalline ZnCu-MOF-74 and effect of mechanochemical amorphization on structure and performance of this bimetallic MOF. The results showed that the nodes coordination spheres changed due to amorphization and breaking of carboxylate metal bonds. As a result of the formation of more active sites due to amorphization, the performance of the electrocatalyst has been reported to improve. Importantly, amorphization improves the electrocatalyst selectivity for MeOH formation. As a result of these findings, the role of defects in the electrocatalytic structure is more important than porosity in MeOH synthesis, causing CO2RR to be performed at the MOF surface. Another important point in the performance and selectivity of the product in CO2RR is the control of intermediate binding. Based on this point, Nam et al. utilized isoreticular MOFs for CO2RR [176]. In this work, adsorption of CO2 was regulated by changing the metal nodes and amine-functionalized linkers resulting in the Ag nanoparticles-immobilized face-centered cubic MOF. Based on X-ray adsorption spectroscopy, they confirmed the stability of this material with lower overpotential in CO2RR. In describing the performance of this electrocatalyst, they stated an enhancement in the *CO binging in bridge or atop modes by the regulation and limiting the pore size and amine interaction to facilitate CO2RR path to the product. Heterogeneous electrocatalysts are benefited from features such as the ability to remove processes such as aggregation of catalysts species and dimerization, thus better control of the electrocatalyst surrounding environment and active sites to finally improve the electrocatalyst performance. Heterogenization also prevents oxidation and reduction half-reactions in a cell, avoiding the destruction of the catalyst surface. In heterogeneous systems, as the kinetics of the reaction is not limited by the diffusion rate of catalysts and their solubility, the molecular scale will result in higher electrocatalyst performance. Therefore, MOF thin films can be a proper choice due to their high surface area for molecular CO2 reduction. MOF thin films formed a porous and ordered network, leading to the free diffusion of electrolyte ions and dissolved CO within the film. Accordingly, Fe-porphyrin MOF-525 thin films were utilized for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction due to their good molecular-scale porosity and excellent stability. CV curves confirmed that Fe-porphyrin MOF-525 is responsible for electrocatalytic performance. Results of the investigations also indicated that the product of this reaction included a mixture of CO and H2 [177]. Cu-based electrocatalysts are a group of electrocatalysts that have gained a considerable deal of attention due to their high reaction rate in the production of hydrocarbons especially CH4 and C2H4 under mild conditions. They, however, produce a mixture of gas and liquid byproducts with low Faradic efficiency during CO2RR, posing a serious challenge in high-selectivity CO2RR. Gas capture and adsorption play a decisive role in CO2RR. In this regard, Cu2O has exhibited a promising role in CO2RR toward the formation of hydrocarbons with high efficiency, it, however, suffers from poor stability in electrochemical tests. To resolve this problem, a Cu2O@Cu-MOF hybrid was synthesized whose CO2RR performance was assessed [178]. The results indicated a rise in the specific surface area relative to Cu2O upon the formation of the hybrid. Moreover, CO2 adsorption capacity showed a 10-fold increase compared to Cu2O. The Faradic efficiency of 79.4% and 63.2% was reported for C2H4 + CH4 and CH4, respectively. Synergistic effect of Cu2O and Cu-MOF was also effective in this performance (Fig. 15 a(i–iii)). In another study by Wu et al., Cu-porphyrin MOF was reported in CO2RR which resulted in the formation of acetate and formate with high Faradic efficiency [179]. Wang et al. synthesized CuO/Cu-MOF nanosheets through a solvothermal method to be used in CO2RR. Their results indicated that this nanocomposite provided numerous sites for CO2RR and its ethylene Faradic efficiency was reported 50%. Such efficiency showed a small reduction to about 45% after successive polarization. Such a proper performance can be assigned to the 2D structure of MOF and the useful connection between CuO and MOF which resulted in a synergistic effect between the metals [180]. Zirconium porphyrinic-MOFs (PCN-223-M) could be a proper candidate for electrocatalytic reactions including CO2RR due to its uncoordinated zirconium sites. For instance, Zr-MOF was reported as an electrocatalyst for CO2RR with controlled uncoordinated zirconium sites and high selectivity [181]. A negative correlation was observed between the CO2RR performance and zirconium sites as a rise in zirconium sites declined the CO2RR performance of PCN-233-M. This strategy makes it possible to set the performance and selectivity of CO2RR (Fig. 15b(i, ii)). Metal catecholate plays a key role in electron transfer due to metal-catechol orbital overlap. Therefore, they could be an ideal candidate for electrocatalytic oxidation and reduction reactions. In this regard, Matheu et al. (2019) synthesized catecholate MOF-1992 and utilized it for CO2RR [182]. Bismuth-based materials have been used as ideal electrocatalysts in the CO2RR due to low toxicity and low cost. According to reports, the primary CO2RR products resulting from the use of these materials were formate and CO [183–185]. Single-atom electrocatalysts, on the other hand, have been the focus of researchers due to their unique electronic structure and maximum use of atomic sites [186–188]. MOFs show themselves here as well, and they may be the best option. Zhang et al. could synthesize single Bi atoms on N-doped carbon networks using a Bi-MOF as a precursor and introduce it as an electrocatalyst for CO2RR in 2019 [189]. This electrocatalyst was obtained in the applied potential window, H2, CO, and formate products, according to the results. Reasons for the stability of this electrocatalyst for CO2RR are morphology, state of surface, and good dispersion of atomic Bi. Based on the proposed CO2RR path in this work, the Gibbs electrocatalyst has less free energy to form *COOH intermediate, indicating the need for less onset potential for CO2RR and CO is formed, and thus it has the lowest overpotential and highest Faradaic efficiency (Fig. 16 a(i, ii)). Controlling materials reconstruction is required for the correct and logical design of advanced electrocatalysts by accurately identifying active sites and clarifying their reaction mechanism in working condition. Reconstruction is a change in an electrocatalyst's structure, composition, or surface [190–192]. Yao et al. used Bi-MOF nanorods (Bi-MOF NR) to study CO2RR in their study. The group converted Bi-MOF NR to (Bi2O2CO3 NS) Bi2O2CO3 nanosheets and Bi nanosheets (Bi NS) in two steps (Fig. 16b(i-iii)) [62]. CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 has been shown to have excellent selectivity, stability, and activity for formate production in CO2RR. Many active Bi sites were formed during reconstruction, resulting in excellent performance. Energy barriers between CO2 and intermediates are lower in bimetallic electrocatalysts than in single metal electrocatalysts, resulting in a decrease in overpotential and an increase in CO2RR selectivity. In bimetallic electrocatalysts, however, replacing some atoms of edge that absorb the H2 molecule with atoms that absorb the CO2 molecule suppresses the HER's competitive response to the CO2RR, making the CO2RR more efficient. According to research, Cu-based bimetallic electrocatalysts perform well with lower overpotential, high stability and selectivity for CO2RR [158,193–195]. By controlling the coordination number, Cu clusters provide a large number of active sites at the electrocatalyst surface. Nonetheless, for Cu-MOFs, the challenge of good performance and selectivity required for formate in CO2RR remains. To address this issue, Yang et al. synthesized CuBi-MOF as a precursor in 2021 and, after calcination, obtained CuBi electrocatalysts [196]. CuBi75 had the highest current density and onset potential at 20 mV according to LSV curves in a CO2 saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 electrolyte sample (Fig. 17 a). CuBi75 has the highest Faradaic efficiency (FEformate) (Fig. 17b). DFT studies were used to investigate the path of converting CO2 to formate. Fig. 17(c and d) depicts this path. According to this figure, DFT studies show that the HCOO* pathway has the lowest amount of free energy, making it the most desirable path for converting CO2 to formate. Sikdar et al. reported the synthesis of a series of MOF-derived Cu x O y C z catalysts by pyrolysis in various temperatures which were then used to assess CO2RR performance (Fig. 18 a and b). The incorporation of various amounts of PTFE in the electrode preparation method affected the performance of the electrode [197]. The highest Faradic efficiency was reported at optimal values. Knowing that MOF-74 has a low dimensional structure and prevents the accumulation of reduced Cu clusters, Kim et al. utilized MOF-74 as a precursor to synthesize Cu nanoparticle clusters to be used in CO2RR for the production of methane. They observed high performance and selectivity in CO2RR for methane production (Fig. 18c) [198]. Li et al. reported Cu-MOF derived Cu2O/Cu@NC in 2020 as a CO2RR electrocatalyst [199]. Cu2O/Cu@NC exhibited high selectivity for the formation of formate relative to ethanol which can be assigned to the abundance of active sites due to the uniform dispersion of Cu2O/Cu in carbon material. The possibility of *OCHO was promoted due to the abundance of N in Cu2O/Cu lattice which guided CO2RR toward the formation of formate with high performance and efficiency. Owing to their electrical features, nitrogen-doped carbon-supported metal catalysts are a proper candidate for electrocatalysts. Interestingly, the selectivity of the product and their electrocatalytic performance depend on the metal configuration in the framework of the carbon. Sun et al. prepared Fe-ZIF-8 by high-temperature pyrolysis to produce mesoporous N-doped carbon (mesoNC-Fe) with atomically dispersed Fe sites for CO2RR [200]. This electrocatalyst exhibited high Faradic efficiency for CO. Thanks to the high surface area of this electrocatalyst due to the presence of carbon framework; more active sites were accessible which influenced the performance of the catalyst (Fig. 19 a–c). The entrance and presence of heteroatoms such as P, S, and N effectively improved the electrical and chemical properties of carbon materials [201]. In this regard, Wang et al. adopted a facile method using ZIF-8 precursor to synthesize N-doped carbon materials to be utilized in electroreduction of CO2. The selectivity of this reaction was 78% for the formation of CO. The presence of pyridinic-N and quaternary-N in the carbon material improved the performance of the electrocatalyst by low energy barrier for the formation of *COOH intermediate required for the formation of CO. Moreover, well-defined porosity led to better and more access to active sites in the electrocatalyst structure [202]. Some metals with d10 electronic configuration including main group metals like Pb, Sn and In and transition group metals like Hg and Pb have been used in the production of formate. Some Sn-based materials have high overpotential and low selectivity but they prevent the environmental and cost problems [203,204]. In this regard, many Bi materials have been employed for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to formate [205,206]. In a study by Deng et al., a Bi-MOF was used as a precursor to synthesize Bi2O3@C to be employed as an electrocatalyst for CO2 reduction. Among the samples, the lowest onset potential and the highest efficiency belonged to Bi2O3@C-800. The electrochemical analysis also revealed that the presence of carbon matrix in the electrocatalyst can enhance the current density while the existence of Bismuth oxides incremented the selectivity and improved the kinetics of the reaction [207]. 3.6 Nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) NH3 is an essential chemical material in fertilizers, potential transportation fuel, and energy carriers. This chemical material plays a decisive role in the plastic and textile industries as well as agriculture. NH3 can be synthesized by three different methods including the Baber-bosch process, azobacter nitrogen fixation, and electrocatalysis (Fig. 20 ) [108]. Currently, NH3 production is achieved through the Haber-Bosch process using Fe- or Ru-based catalyst at high temperatures and pressures releasing huge amounts of CO2 into nature. Therefore, an environmentally friendly alternative with high efficiency is highly welcome. Electrochemical methods and application of electrochemical reaction could be a solution with the least contamination and highest efficiency. N2 reduction reaction (NRR) is capable of producing NH3 at high efficiency through an electrochemical approach. Based on the obtained knowledge, the choice of the electrocatalyst plays a decisive role in different types of electrocatalytic oxidation and reduction reactions. The reasonable design and synthesis of the electrocatalysts is another important point. In this regard, MOFs have found extensive application in NRR due to their unique properties in oxidation and reduction reactions as mentioned earlier. An efficient conductive Cu-MOF containing 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxybenzophenol (HHTP) ligand showed a good performance with 3.34% Faradaic efficiency for NRR [208]. The presence of the thiol (–SH) group on the surface can be effective in the immobilization of the Au nanoparticles (NPs) on MOF. The As –SH groups tend to form S-S bonds, they can offer sulfur-rich sites for immobilization of Au NPs.
