This strategy could be an effective approach in the fabrication of disulfide-containing MOFs to modulate the dispersion of Au NPs. Dynamic covalent chemistry and coordination chemistry provided this opportunity. In this regard, He et al reported the application of a three-dimensional MOF: -bis(mercapto)biphenyl-p,p′-dicarboxylic acid 3,3′ and revealed the formation of a caged-shaped disulfide trimer in the synthesized MOF. The presence of numerous disulfide bonds, as well as a stable structure, introduced this MOF as an excellent matrix for the immobilization of Au NPs. They utilized HT Au@MOF for NRR due to the active sites of Au NPs and hydrophobicity in the MOF shell (Fig. 21 a(i–iii)) the highest Faradic efficiency for NRR and NH3 production was 49.5 μg h−1 mgcat −1 [209]. One of the approaches to resolve the problem of poor conductivity of MOFs could be the formation of 2D MOFs nanosheets. As mentioned in the other parts of this review article, 2D MOFs offer a huge number of active sites for catalytic reactions, hence, facilitating the ion/mass transfer during these reactions. On the other hand, heterometallic MOFs can offer advantages such as increased active sites and improved conductivity, making them an ideal candidate for electrocatalytic reactions. For instance, Li et al. employed Co X Fe-MOF as an electrocatalyst in the NRR, reporting Faradic efficiency and NH3 yield of 25.64% and 8.79 μg h−1 mgcat −1 at KOH 1 M [210]. Conductive MOFs containing hexahydroxytriphenylene (HHTP) or hexaiminotriphenylene (HITP) were reported in electrochemical applications such as capacitors and chemoresistive sensors. In this context, Xiong et al. utilized a Co3HHTP2 for NRR with Faradaic efficiency of 3.34 and NH3 yield of 22.14 μg h−1 mgcat −1 [211]. 2p orbitals of N element can form strong bonds with the p band of main group elements such as Al, B, and Bi, offering an ideal candidate for NRR. On the other hand, main group element-based electrocatalysts are more promising than transition metal groups in NRR as they limit the competition of HER with NRR. Thanks to the strong connection between active sites and N atoms in the structure of MIL-100 (Al), Fu et al. reported the high electrocatalytic performance of this electrocatalyst in NRR. The low cost and high performance of this catalyst make it a promising catalyst in large-scale NRR [212]. Modification of electronic structure can result in electrocatalysts with electron-deficient sites, hence, increasing the affinity of the electrocatalyst for N2, providing an efficient strategy to enhance NRR performance. Electrocatalysts with high N2-binding tendency have shown high NRR performance. Electrocatalysts with lower d-band positions have shown lower hydrogen adsorption tendency, hence they do not participate in HER, while showing high NRR tendency. On the other hand, modification of the electronic structure of the electrocatalysts to increase the number of sites with high N2 affinity can improve NRR performance. Sim et al. modified the electronic structure of ZIF and reached the Faradic efficiency of 44% and NH3 yield of 161 μg h−1 mgcat −1. Using a layer of ZIF, Pt/Au catalyst was capsulated by interactions, and the d-band had no tendency to hydrogen adsorption, offering numerous sites for interaction with N2, enhancing the possibility of NRR (Fig. 21b(i–iii)) [213]. In another study, the hydrophobic layer of ZIF declined the possibility of competitive HER relative to NRR, resulting in proper NRR. High hydrophobicity will repel water molecules from the surface, eliminating the possibility of HER reaction. This research was carried out by Lee et al. and their interesting strategy could be generalized to other materials as well [214]. MXenes have shown surface hydrophilicity and high electronic conductivity and can be employed in various electrochemical applications including NRR. Upon compositing, they can improve the performance of the composite [215,216]. Liang et al reported a successful synthesis of ZIF-67@Ti3C2Mxen and used them for NRR under ambient conditions. Thanks to the high porosity and surface area of ZIF-67 and high electrical conductivity of Ti3C2 Mxen, the obtained composite can exhibit excellent NRR performance in 0.1 M KOH with NH3 yield of 6.52 μmol h−1 cm−2 and the highest Faradaic efficiency [216]. Transition metal ions or clusters are one of the redox active sites for electrochemical redox reactions. Among them, Mo is an abundant element that can be employed in NRR. A 2D Mo-MOF was examined in a theoretical study based on the DFT approach. The results indicated the strong adsorption of N2 by this structure which showed the high selectivity of this electrocatalyst, leading to the lowest overpotential through the most desirable mechanism. Many MOF-based electrocatalysts for use in a wide range of energy-related oxidation and reduction reactions have demonstrated improved performance to date, which has been discussed above. Despite the progress made in these areas, there are still challenges to the future use of these materials in the field of energy, which should be addressed. It is worth noting that most pristine MOFs have low conductivity, whereas MOF-derived carbon materials have higher conductivity than pristine MOFs. One of the important factors that can limit the overall performance of MOFs in energy-related oxidation and reduction reactions is low electrical conductivity. As a result, the advancement of high-conductivity and improved MOFs may provide an opportunity to design efficient electrocatalysts [78,217]. Stability in long operation is very important in practical applications of the electrocatalysts. Because, the material during long-term cycling might undergoes some changes in the structure, composition, and morphology. In a limited number of studies, the structure of MOF-based electrocatalysts has been identified after long stability tests, and the study of this issue affects practical applications of these electrocatalysts. Another significant challenge is to comprehend and precisely identify the mechanism of reactions, because a thorough understanding of the mechanism of reactions can serve as a logical foundation for the design of advanced electrocatalysts. Advances in quantum chemistry and the integration of experimental and theory sciences are expected to open up new avenues for the development of MOF-based electrocatalysts for use in energy-related reactions. Single-atom catalysts with metal atoms as their active centers can enhance the chance of the participation of unsaturated metals in the reaction [218,219]. These single-atom catalysts have high activity and selectivity and can act as a bridge between heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts [220,221]. Reports have indicated the efficiency of Fe-dinitrogen complexes for NRR [222]. On the other hand, the presence of Fe is essential for biological fixation in nitrogenase [223–225]. Accordingly, Zhang et al. employed porphyrinic MOF (PCN-222) as a precursor for NRR and reported single-atom Fe implanted nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts (Fe1-N-C) using a mixed ligand technique. Good conductivity, porosity, and highly dispersed single atom Fe site resulted in the highest efficiency in Fe1-N-C. DFT calculations also confirmed much lower energy barriers compared to their Ni and Co counterparts (Fig. 22 a) [226]. Transition metal oxides derived from MOFs have several advantages such as abundant pores and high surface area, which facilitate the charge transfer with more accessible active sites. In addition, the controllability of their structure facilitates their applications in electrochemical reactions. Based on the literature, MOF-derived transition metal oxides have been used in the NRR. For example, in 2019, Luo et al. reported MOF-derived nitrogen-doped carbon/Co3O4 nanocomposites (Co3O4@NCs) with a core/shell structure as an efficient electrocatalyst for NRR. This group observed high NH3 yield and efficiency, which could be justified by the formation of the core/shell structure as well as the synergistic effect between Co3O4 and N-doped carbon (Fig. 22b and c) [227]. In another study, Gao et al. used ZIF-67 as a precursor for pyrolysis at different temperatures to reach Co/NC-T (T stands for pyrolysis at different temperatures) [228]. They applied this electrocatalyst for NH3 production using NRR. The interesting point was the preservation of structural topologies of ZIF-67. therefore, the electrocatalyst derived from it had a high surface area with ideal stability. Concerning the performance of this electrocatalyst, the production efficiency of NH3 in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte solution was equal to 5.1 μgNH3 h− 1, which can be justified by the pyrrolic N and single Co atoms acting as active sites. Performance of MOF-based materials for different energy-related oxidation and reduction reactions summarize in Table 1 . 4 MOFs as electrocatalysts for sensing-related oxidation and reduction reactions Electrochemical sensors have been employed in various applications, including control of food quality, chemical treat detection, medical diagnostics, and environmental science. The selectivity and sensitivity of sensors are two important factors in their electrochemical performance. MOFs are suitable candidates in this field due to their large surface area and porous structure, which facilitate the loading of guest molecules into their pores, promoting their catalytic performance, which finally results in excellent sensitivity in electrochemical detection. MOF selectivity is derived from interactions such as open metal sites, hydrogen bonding, π-π interactions and Van der Waals interactions between guest molecules and MOFs. Furthermore, the shape and size of the pores in MOFs cause selectivity based on the shape and size of the guest molecules. Despite all of the appealing properties of MOFs for surface modification of electrodes, signal transduction is the most difficult aspect of using these materials as electrochemical sensors. Not all MOFs are suitable for chemical sensing. Conductive and redox-active MOFs have demonstrated satisfactory electrochemical performance. Combining MOFs with other functional materials, such as biomolecules and carbon materials, has also helped to improve their performance [244]. So, in this section, MOF-based electrochemical sensors used to perform oxidation and reduction reactions are investigated. 4.1 Glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) Glucose is involved in a variety of cellular processes. A healthy person's glucose concentration should be between 4.4 and 6.6 mM. If the glucose level is lower than normal or higher than normal, it can lead to diseases such as diabetes and hypoglycemia, as well as other health problems such as heart disease, kidney failure, and a variety of other issues [245]. As a result, monitoring the amount of glucose in the blood is critical. Because of the disadvantages of enzyme-based electrochemical glucose sensors, such as sensitivity to pH and temperature, non-enzymatic glucose sensors have been developed, which in this category is one of the most important factors in selecting the appropriate electrode material. Researchers are looking for electrode materials that are sensitive to glucose. According to one report, Xiao et al. used CuNi-MOF as a precursor and used a simple method to obtain metal/metal oxide@carbon composites (M/MO@C) [246]. Sensing tests were carried out by adding different amounts of glucose to a 0.1 M NaOH solution. The studies in this group showed that the electrode material M/MO@C-800 has good selectivity and stability, as well as a low detection limit, due to the presence of porous carbon and the synergistic effect between Cu and Ni in the composite (Fig. 23 a). According to another report from the Feng group, NiCo2O4 hollow nanocages (NiCo2O4 HNCs) derived ZIF-67 with more active sites and a higher surface area demonstrated good electrochemical behavior for glucose sensing with a fast response time and good selectivity (Fig. 23b) [247]. Because the reaction of glucose oxidation in alkaline solution is more desirable for metal oxides, they used NaOH as the electrolyte [248]. Wearable sensors, which provide instant information for disease diagnosis, are one type of sensor that has recently received a lot of attention. Despite their allure and advances in sensing technology, most commercial models do not provide accurate health data [249]. As a result, more research in this field is required to gain a thorough understanding and accurate health information. Pd@ZIF-67 was introduced as an electrochemical sensor for glucose detection based on glucose oxidation in a study by the Zhu Group [250]. In this study, alkaline pH condition for glucose oxidation was provided by reaction of water splitting (Fig. 24 a–c). The use of Pd nanoparticles in this study ensured the detection of glucose due to the reduction of hydrogen bubbles. ZIF-67 increases surface area and improves the electrocatalytic performance. 4.2 Dichlorophen oxidation reaction (DOR) Dichlorophen (Dcp) is a very toxic substance in aquatic environments and is very harmful to organisms. It is primarily used in pharmaceuticals and pesticides. As a result, determining the identity of this substance is critical [251,252]. This is what Tu et al. did in a study using rGO@Ce-MOF, and the results were published in 2019 [253]. The encapsulated structure in this group's electrode material prevented the MOF structure from decomposing in solution. The composite, on the other hand, has shown improved conductivity. Furthermore, due to the synergistic effect of rGO and MOF, the detection of Dcp is in the wide range of 0.02−10 M, with a detection limit of 0.007 M reported. 4.3 Nitrite oxidation reaction (NOR) Despite the fact nitrite is extremely hazardous to human health and is a highly toxic species, it is used as a fertilizer and preservation agent in many environmental and food systems. Nitrite causes irreversible oxidation of hemoglobin to methomoglobin, which is incapable of carrying oxygen in the body. In addition, toxic and carcinogenic compounds such as N-nitroso are formed as a result of its interaction with amines. As a result, sensitive methods for nitrite detection will be critical, with electrochemical sensors shining due to their low detection limit, good selectivity, and high sensitivity. However, because the potential for nitrite oxidation is so high, it is critical to develop efficient electrode materials for nitrite sensors. MOFs and MOF-based materials have been used as modified electrodes in the development of nitrite sensors. Metalloporphyrinic MOF is an example of a redox-active MOF. Pila et al. synthesized and reported a series of metalloporphyrinic MOFs with Ni, Fe, Mn, and H (PCN-222 (M)) as thin films on carbon fiber paper in their study [254]. In Eq. (13), electrochemical reactions for the conversion of NO2 − to NO3 − are given. As demonstrated by the reactions, metals in their divalent state are electroactive centers. Electrochemical tests were carried out in KCl 0.1 M + 0.75 mM NaNO2, and among the various metals tested, Ni thin films reacted better with a high current density 950 μA cm−2. It is worth noting that carbon fiber papers have proven to be an effective substrate for this reaction as well as the performance of the electrode material. (13) NO 2 - + H 2 O → NO 3 - + 2 H + + 2 e - The Yuan Group used a stable 3-dimensional Cu-MOF synthesized by solvothermal method for nitrite oxidation in another report. According to the report, the Cu-MOF sensor's low oxidation potential, wide linear range, and low detection limit for nitrite indicate high sensor efficiency. After 2500 s, the amperometric response of this sensor to nitrite remains at 98% of its original value [255]. Graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) with edge morphology, adjustable electrical properties, and functionality are amenable to use in electrochemistry, including electrochemical sensors. GNRs can also function as conductive supports. Based on this information, the Kung team reported MOF-525/GNRs that can be used as electrochemical sensor of nitrite [256]. In this composite, GNRs act as conductive bridges to facilitate transport of charge and MOFs provide a large surface area for the electrochemical reaction to take place. The performance of an electrochemical nitrite sensor was investigated using an amperometric technique on a thin film of MOF/GNRs-50. The experiments were carried out at 0.1 M KCl and in the presence of various concentrations of nitrite. The nitrite sensor linear range was in the range of 100–2500 μM, with a detection limit of 0.75 μM. The structure–property relationship approves this performance was due to the unique structure of MOF with high surface area. 4.4 L-cystein oxidation reaction (COR) L-cystein (CySH), an important amino acid that plays an important role in protein biological activity, medicine, food, and pharmaceuticals, is another widely used and important substance worth monitoring [257]. Because of their properties such as renewable surface, high surface area, high conductivity, and good biocompatibility, nanoparticles (NPs) are used in a variety of modified electrodes. The important point about the application of Au NPs in terms of their electrocatalytic performance is their size and shape control, and if these NPs are immobilized on solid support material surface, they can have the highest electrocatalytic performance because in this case, NPs are accessible and have high dispersion; their morphology and size are controllable and show high stability. In the meantime, MOF can demonstrate its effectiveness and be used as a support. Hosseini et al. introduced a new electrochemical sensor Au-SH-SiO2@Cu-MOF for CySH oxidation and detection [258]. The performance of this new sensor was investigated in phosphate buffer solution at pH = 5. Based on the CV results, an anodic peak related to CySH oxidation at a lower potential and increased current is observed in Au-SH-SiO2@Cu-MOF/GCE, indicating the capability of this sensor for CySH oxidation, and this capability is attributed to the porosity and high surface area that the MOF has provided for this new sensor. This sensor's detection studies have also revealed a broad linear range and a lower detection limit for CySH. 4.5 Isoniazid oxidation reactions (IOR) Isoniazid (INZ) is a drug that has a strong antibacterial effect and is used to treat tuberculosis. Given that high dosage taking of this drug cause liver poisoning, the subject of detection is important for INZ, and because it contains nitrile groups in its structure that are prone to oxidation, the detection ability of this compound is enhanced by electrochemical method. A suitable electrocatalyst should be designed and used to facilitate this. Wang et al. introduced a new MOF-derived NiO@ZnO sensor and tested it as an electrochemical INZ sensor in 2020, as shown in Fig. 25 (a) [259]. This composite's hollow spheres morphology combines the advantages of the two metal oxides, resulting in excellent electrocatalytic performance for INZ oxidation. It is stated that oxidation peaks have appeared in DPV patterns in PB solution containing a certain concentration of INZ, and the current of peak for MOF-derived NiO@ZnO has increased significantly compared to bare indicates the excellent performance of this material for the INZ oxidation reaction (Fig. 25b). The sensing performance of INZ was 50–100 M. The use of MOF-based materials for electrochemical sensing reactions was investigated in this section, despite reports in this field and the unique properties of MOFs that make them an ideal choice for electrochemical sensing, in this direction. And challenges remain for the development of MOF-based sensing applications. Given that operations in electrochemical sensing systems must be performed primarily in aqueous solutions, the rational design of a MOF structure that is stable in water is critical, and because most MOFs are less stable in aqueous solutions, this has become a challenge in the field of applying Pristine MOFs for sensing. Because the ions in the solution will change as the structure of MOFs degrades in solution. To overcome this challenge, the appropriate metal nodes and linkers must be selected. Furthermore, the low conductivity of MOFs presents a significant challenge for electrochemical sensing. To address this issue, strategies such as using MOFs with redox-active centers or obtaining different derivatives of MOFs with higher conductivity than pristine MOFs can be employed. Performance of MOF-based materials for different sensing-related oxidation and reduction reactions summarize in Table 2 . 5 Conclusions Pristine MOFs and their composites have been recently developed for electrocatalytic purposes due to their high surface area and proper pore size distribution. These electrocatalysts can be employed in a wide range of electrochemical oxidation and reduction reactions for energy and sensing applications with performances comparable with those of conventional electrocatalysts. The structure of MOFs can be controlled by structural engineering and tuning their morphology through changing nodes and linkers as well as surface area. Numerous active sites can be formed on their surface by inducing structural defects which can improve the electrocatalytic performance of MOFs. The function of an electrocatalyst drastically depends on its electronic structure. Intermediate binding strength to the electrocatalyst surface indeed determines the performance and selectivity of the resulting system. Therefore, desired results can be achieved by a reasonable design of the electrocatalyst structure. In this review, energy- and sensing-related electrochemical oxidation and reduction reactions such as ORR, CRR, UOR, GOR, and NRR are presented based on the relationship between the structure and performance, describing various strategies to overcome some of the major challenges. Despite recent reports on advances in MOFs and their composites, following limitations and challenges have remained in our journey to widespread application of MOF-based electrocatalysts: (1) Regarding the low conductivity of MOFs, the development of conductive MOFs or the improvement of their conductivity could enhance the electrocatalytic function of these compounds. Researchers are in search for novel approaches to improve and increase the conductivity of MOFs. Structurally, the use of conductive nodes and linkers can increase charge and mass transport. Conductive MOFs comprising Metal-X bonds (X = N, O, S) have been recently considered. Therefore, conductive MOF nanosheets open opportunities to design efficient electrocatalysts. Another strategy to enhance the conductivity of MOFs is to mix MOFs with some conductive materials such as carbon or deposit MOFs on a conductive substrate. Compared pristine MOFs, MOF-containing nanocomposites have shown improved performance and better stability. (2) The development of redox-active MOFs can be achieved by understanding the relationship between their structure and function. Moreover, active sites can be formed in MOFs by using clusters containing active sites. (3) The design of efficient electrocatalysts with improved performance and acceptable stability is an important challenge. A deep and detailed understanding of the mechanism of involved reactions will facilitate the design of efficient electrocatalysts while elucidating the relationship between structure and performance of MOFs. (4) Difficult synthesis of some ligands and MOFs involving the use of several, possible harmful chemicals, is another challenge. More importantly, they are unstable in aqueous solutions, further restricting their large-scale production and applications. (5) Stability is an important factor in practical applications of these materials, as their structure and performance may change in long-term operations. Surface modification can resolve this limitation by improving their stability in aqueous solutions. (6) Knowledge on the structural changes and intermediates formed during electrocatalytic reactions is vital in exploring the electrocatalyst efficiency. A combination of in-situ experimental techniques and theoretical calculations can help in this regard. (7) A deep understanding of a relationship between the performance and the structure of the electrocatalyst is necessary in the electrode reactions which are missing in most of them. This issue can be resolved by elucidating of the transfer mechanism and deep understanding of structural properties. (8) A serious challenge introducing low cost electrocatalysts in large-scale. Filling the gap of industrial and laboratory studies can result in highly efficient electrocatalysts at lower costs. (9) Study of oxidation and reduction electrode reactions in the MOFs is still in a primary step. The industrial application of MOF-based electrocatalysts has remained problematic which can be solved by further research and optimizing protocols. The effective strategies and further studies to achieve great electrocatalytic activity in these electrode reactions can promote large-scale commercial and industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Studies have extensively addressed the development of electrocatalytic technologies for energy storage and conversion, fuel production, and environmental protection. Electrode processes such as different oxidation and reduction reactions play a vital and significant role in these technologies. In this regard, efficient, inexpensive, and stable electrocatalysts capable can significantly promote electrochemical reactions. Unique features of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) such as their high porosity, tunable structure, size, and pore shape, high surface area, and redox properties have introduced them as an ideal electrocatalyst candidate. This review is thus aimed at elucidating the role of MOF-based materials (pristine, derivatives and composites) as efficient electrocatalysts in energy and sensing-related oxidation and reduction reactions such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), urea oxidation reaction (UOR), alcohol oxidation reaction (AOR), nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), and glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) in advanced energy and sensing devices. Also, the structure–property relationship of the electrocatalyst was elaborated for each electrocatalytic reaction. Finally, perspectives on the potential research topics for practical use of MOF-based electrocatalysts are addressed. The present review can improve the interest in MOF-based electrocatalysts to study different oxidation and reduction reactions in energy and sensing systems.
